text: What's up everybody, Eric here, and I am back with David Hunter. I was just chat with him real quick before we started. This is the fourth time he and I are meeting and it's actually really useful at least for my perspective because I get to understand his thought process then as we get new data, how that impacts his thought process because really you're teaching us different ways to think about markets and the economy. And I think that that's just tremendously valuable. So first off, welcome back, great to have you. Yeah, thanks Eric. Glad to be back. Yeah, and since the last time we spoke, there has been no shortage of drama in the economy and the market. So I'm really eager to get into, you know, how you think things are rolling out and what you're looking at. So I figure we could start a little bit about the broader markets. Last time we spoke again, it was about three months ago. We were talking about this idea of recession and I had asked you if you thought we were in a recession at that point, you said you thought so if not right on the precipice of entering one. And I'm curious how have your thoughts evolved around that concept? What are your thoughts on our position in relation to a recession? Yeah, for sure. Since I think we spoke in June. So, so after after that last conversation, we obviously got second quarter

metadata.title: Market Bottomed and Headed to Top in 6 Months Before 80% Global Bust with David Hunter

text: the precipice of entering one. And I'm curious how have your thoughts evolved around that concept? What are your thoughts on our position in relation to a recession? Yeah, for sure. Since I think we spoke in June. So, so after after that last conversation, we obviously got second quarter G P in, you know, later in July. And it confirmed that we had two quarters of negative GDP, which by, you know, traditional definition, that's a recession. You know, there's lots of ways to kind of look at what is, you know, whether it's a recession or not. But I think for sure, the economy's weak. I think technically we're in a recession. I think more than technically, you know, the economy was showing negative GDP. Third quarter, we bounced a bit, not a lot, but you know, a little bit. So, you know, you can argue that we may have stopped the negative. But I think we're heading for much deeper weakness. And so, you know, you're going to in recession, you're going to go in and out of GDP, positive GDP, negative GDP, until you really get into the depth of the recession. So, you know, my view, which has not changed is that we're on our way to a global bust. I define a global bust and actually a global deflationary bust. I define that as something bigger than a recession, but not as long as a depression. It might have some of the characteristics of

metadata.title: Market Bottomed and Headed to Top in 6 Months Before 80% Global Bust with David Hunter

text: view, which has not changed is that we're on our way to a global bust. I define a global bust and actually a global deflationary bust. I define that as something bigger than a recession, but not as long as a depression. It might have some of the characteristics of a depression, but happened in kind of a concentrate period time, like a year. So, I think, you know, 2008-09 was almost a bust, but they saved it before really got into that. So, I think this time we see something worse than 2008-09, which would make it the worse since the Great Depression. And I think it'll be accompanied by a financial crisis, the likes of which we have not seen. So, bigger than 2008-09. And that means, you know, bank failure is a lot of involuntary debt liquidation. You know, lots of unpleasant things. I think that's likely second half of 2023. You know, you never know exactly when, because we're recession into a global bust. Isn't two different things. It's just it takes a while for you to move into the real depths of it and where you get to the point where the financial crisis gets big enough where it causes a bust. So, like I said, we haven't seen one in post-war or two-era. We came close in 2008-09. I think this is going to surprise people in terms of the magnitude. But before we get there, you know, you're going to be kind of

Ultimately, I think we're going to have a hard landing. Well, that actually leads beautifully into my next question, which is last time we talked about exactly that, the concepts of soft landing, hard landing, and the way that markets have been moving in relation to which one of those is more likely. Last time, you also felt that we were more likely leaning towards a hard landing. It sounds like that's about the same. text: feds in transit and transigence in terms of rate hikes and feeling like they have to go a lot farther. We've seen rate increases at a speed that is beyond, there's no precedent for the speed with which rates have gone up. The fed doesn't think their work is done. They keep talking about another 75, but maybe another 75 in November, December, and then maybe pause there or maybe do some more hikes in 2023. That's got the market very spooked and for good reason. In past times, you know, I've been through many cycles and I've watched the fed through many cycles.
